description: EC-Council's Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) certification covers concepts and tools related to exploiting systems, networks, devices and operating platforms. It is designed to get an individual into the world of pen testing to learn techniques of how to test a network or infrastructure. This includes hacking concepts such as vulnerability assessment, network intrusion, reverse engineering, defacing websites, damaging network appliances, launching distributed denial-of-service attacks, massive worm propagation, breaking passwords, brute-forcing authentication systems, cracking encryption, exploiting systems, advance viruses, Trojans, and other malware. This certificate is targeted at site administrators, security professionals, auditors and anyone who is concerned about the integrity of the network infrastructure that has practical real world experience to support this type of equipment.
name: CEH v8
subtitle: Certified Ethical Hacker

episodes.description: Properly securing servers and networks is a significant challenge due to the ever changing attack methods used by hackers. The most successful security technicians have a thorough understanding of the tools and techniques used by the hackers themselves. This practical knowledge of attack methods allows a defender to assemble more flexible protections for their systems. The Certified Ethical Hacker certification is designed to bridge the gap between theoretical and practical knowledge. This is the first step to becoming a Penetration Tester and increasing your ability to secure a network.

see if there's anything else you
need to kind of fill out, and

1463
01:16:57,900 --> 01:17:04,010
then getting ready to carry that on to the
enumeration section of the scanning phase.

1464
01:17:04,010 --> 01:17:04,530
>> Right.
Very good, yes.

1465
01:17:04,530 --> 01:17:08,240
We've got our deliverables, our stuff
that's coming out of the previous phase.

1466
01:17:08,240 --> 01:17:10,060
That's gonna be the input,
and then in the next phase,

1467
01:17:10,060 --> 01:17:13,200
in our next phase after scanning, we've
done footprinting, we've done scanning.

1468
01:17:13,200 --> 01:17:15,320
Next one is gonna be that enumeration for
us.

1469
01:17:16,880 --> 01:17:19,520
And another good question out there in
the chatroom before we kill this one.

1470
01:17:19,520 --> 01:17:23,300
I think I saw something about
are these scanners able to scan VMs.

1471
01:17:23,300 --> 01:17:28,130
And absolutely, as Mike pointed out, the

1472
01:17:28,130 --> 01:17:30,270
that I was running that Kali Linux in.

1473
01:17:31,350 --> 01:17:34,360
The issue you might run into
the scanning of virtual machines for

1474

vulnerabilities is there's some hardware
virtualization going on there and

1475
01:17:38,660 --> 01:17:43,360
some other things that could either be
masked from that it might not detect.

1476
01:17:43,360 --> 01:17:45,970
It doesn't realize it's a virtual machine.

1477
01:17:45,970 --> 01:17:48,340
So you might not get the most
accurate results, maybe?

1478
01:17:48,340 --> 01:17:50,280
Would you say that'd be correct?

1479
01:17:50,280 --> 01:17:52,812
>> I think that's fair, yeah.

1480
01:17:52,812 --> 01:17:56,070
>> All right, well ladies and
gentlemen, that is gonna do it for

1481
01:17:56,070 --> 01:17:58,600
our scanning chapter.

1482

Remember this was a part two of scanning.

1483

We've got the part one episode

1484
01:18:03,480 --> 01:18:06,780
Make sure you go back and watch that.

1485
01:18:06,780 --> 01:18:08,920
You know, as always,

1486
01:18:08,920 --> 01:18:12,180
Well let me tell you what we covered

1487
01:18:12,180 --> 01:18:15,815
We are the second, part two,
I can't get it out of my mouth today.

1488
01:18:15,815 --> 01:18:18,100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Part two of our scanning episode,

1489
01:18:18,100 --> 01:18:20,260
we covered things like EnMAP.

1490
01:18:20,260 --> 01:18:23,910
We got a really good look at all
the things we can do with EnMAP.

1491
01:18:23,910 --> 01:18:25,700
We talked about mapping out a network,

1492
01:18:25,700 --> 01:18:29,960
using programs like Friendly Pinger and
SolarWinds.

1493
01:18:29,960 --> 01:18:31,630
We mentioned a couple other ones.

1494
01:18:31,630 --> 01:18:35,200
And then we rounded it off with
a look at vulnerability scanners.

1495
01:18:35,200 --> 01:18:37,430
I showed you guys a demo

1496
01:18:37,430 --> 01:18:41,680
talked about a few one of those and then
what we need to bring out of this phase.

1497
01:18:41,680 --> 01:18:44,450
So remember, if you've got questions
while you're watching this show,

1498
01:18:44,450 --> 01:18:46,640
jump into the chat room and

1499
01:18:46,640 --> 01:18:48,020
That's why that's what we do.

1500
01:18:48,020 --> 01:18:51,570
That's why we're here, to answer

1501
01:18:51,570 --> 01:18:54,620
If you're watching a recording of

1502

Up at the top of every page is a Q&A link.

1506

1
00:00:00,170 --> 00:00:10,170
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,545 --> 00:00:35,295
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

3
00:00:35,295 --> 00:00:38,310
Welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,310 --> 00:00:41,430
I'm your host Mike Rodrick,
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:41,430 --> 00:00:42,660
How you doing today Sean?

6
00:00:42,660 --> 00:00:43,850
>> I'm doing awesome.

7
00:00:43,850 --> 00:00:45,610
>> Awesome, I like to hear it.

8
00:00:45,610 --> 00:00:49,290
Another exciting episode for
everybody out there in TV land.

9
00:00:49,290 --> 00:00:50,740
We've been doing our

10
00:00:51,970 --> 00:00:56,350
CEH study guide written by none
other than Mr.Sean Oriyano.

11
00:00:56,350 --> 00:01:01,140
And we are getting ready to move on
into chapter six, which is enumeration.

12
00:01:01,140 --> 00:01:05,730
We've gone through the different phases
of the hacking lifecycle, if you will.

13
00:01:05,730 --> 00:01:07,070
We've done our footprinting,

14
00:01:07,070 --> 00:01:11,725
we've done our scanning, and
the next phase is going to be enumeration.

15
00:01:11,725 --> 00:01:13,195
Big fancy term, Sean,

16
00:01:13,195 --> 00:01:18,175
for listing or ordered lists or
naming one thing after another.

17
00:01:18,175 --> 00:01:19,605
You see all kinds of definitions for
it, but

18
00:01:19,605 --> 00:01:22,590
it really is just
obtaining a list of things.

19
00:01:22,590 --> 00:01:23,500
>> Yeah absolutely.

20
00:01:23,500 --> 00:01:30,590
I mean, that's what you gave is basically
the dictionary, textbook definition of it.

21
00:01:30,590 --> 00:01:31,945
>> That's where I got it from.

22
00:01:31,945 --> 00:01:33,436
[LAUGH]
>> Good.

23
00:01:33,436 --> 00:01:34,121
>> [LAUGH].

24
00:01:34,121 --> 00:01:36,559
>> Cuz that's where I plagiarized
it from in that book.

25
00:01:36,559 --> 00:01:41,580
No, [LAUGH] in seriousness,
it's fits it pretty nicely.

26
00:01:41,580 --> 00:01:47,540
That's a nice, succinct description when
you talk about what enumeration does.

27
00:01:47,540 --> 00:01:49,820
Yeah, you're gaining lists of things.

28
00:01:49,820 --> 00:01:54,910
So when we talk about doing enumeration,
we are trying to gain lists of different

29
00:01:54,910 --> 00:01:59,890
things on that network, or
on that target, whatever it might be.

30
00:02:01,000 --> 00:02:07,170
So, before we even get into that though,
we kinda need to gather the information.

31
00:02:07,170 --> 00:02:12,224
And I think we kinda need to discuss
just what type of information you can

32
00:02:12,224 --> 00:02:17,545
reasonably expect to get out of a system
or target when you're doing this.

33
00:02:17,545 --> 00:02:18,545
>> Right.

34
00:02:18,545 --> 00:02:22,628
>> And it's actually pretty amazing when
you think about it, what you can get.

35
00:02:22,628 --> 00:02:27,160
If we kind of fit this into what we talked
out in our previous step with scanning.

36
00:02:27,160 --> 00:02:30,830
Scanning, as I said repeatedly,

37
00:02:30,830 --> 00:02:35,100
it's like turning the doorknobs,
seeing which ones are open.

38
00:02:35,100 --> 00:02:38,210
And kind of just, maybe in some
case when you find some open,

39
00:02:38,210 --> 00:02:43,255
looking behind it to see what's back
there in that room, so to speak.

40
00:02:43,255 --> 00:02:46,003
And you gotta remember
when you do scanning,

41
00:02:46,003 --> 00:02:51,220
scanning you're finding stuff that's
open or closed, you're determining that.

42
00:02:51,220 --> 00:02:54,110
Now what we're doing is we're seeing is
there anything back there we can actually

43
00:02:54,110 --> 00:02:56,540
do anything with and
what could we do with it?

44
00:02:57,700 --> 00:02:59,330
>> Yeah and
we've mentioned that a few times,

45
00:02:59,330 --> 00:03:01,400
you'll see that common theme, right.

46
00:03:01,400 --> 00:03:05,920
The data that we gather in a previous
phase is gonna be used in that next phase.

47
00:03:05,920 --> 00:03:09,960
So now that we know what ports are open,
let's go dive through them.

48
00:03:09,960 --> 00:03:12,320
Let's see what kind of
information lies back there and

49
00:03:12,320 --> 00:03:14,690
let's start listing this information out.

50
00:03:14,690 --> 00:03:16,670
>> Yeah, absolutely, I mean,
that's what we're trying to do.

51
00:03:16,670 --> 00:03:20,790
We're trying to list information
by going through and

52
00:03:20,790 --> 00:03:23,610
looking at these various ports and
enumerating,

53
00:03:23,610 --> 00:03:27,780
there's that word again, each one of
those services to see what they reveal.

54
00:03:27,780 --> 00:03:31,040
So what could you expect at this stage,
reasonably expect?

55
00:03:31,040 --> 00:03:34,779
Usernames, of course,
you could definitely get usernames.

56
00:03:34,779 --> 00:03:37,600
You might be able to obtain passwords.

57
00:03:37,600 --> 00:03:44,060
You might be able to obtain
information about system policy.

58
00:03:44,060 --> 00:03:46,340
That's more than possible.

59
00:03:46,340 --> 00:03:50,050
You could get stuff through SNMP, and

60
00:03:50,050 --> 00:03:54,500
we'll talk about what that is so if it's
an alphabet soup right now, that's fine.

61
00:03:54,500 --> 00:03:56,980
You might be able to
get stuff through that.

62
00:03:56,980 --> 00:04:01,556
You can get lists of machines,
lists of shares,

63
00:04:01,556 --> 00:04:05,760
groups, all sorts of interesting things.

64
00:04:05,760 --> 00:04:08,610
You're really digging
into it at this point.

65
00:04:08,610 --> 00:04:13,480
Now, keep in mind,
we haven't really hacked the system.

66
00:04:13,480 --> 00:04:18,210
It's kind of crazy when you look at it,
the amount of information you get,

67
00:04:18,210 --> 00:04:20,530
we're still not saying
we've hacked the system.

68
00:04:20,530 --> 00:04:21,560
We're getting close.

69
00:04:21,560 --> 00:04:24,030
Remember that is the next phase.

70
00:04:24,030 --> 00:04:26,032
We're not in the next phase yet.

71
00:04:26,032 --> 00:04:30,223
We are still in the scanning
phase of hacking.

72
00:04:30,223 --> 00:04:33,924
But there's, and when we look at
the scanning phase, we have scanning and

73
00:04:33,924 --> 00:04:37,120
then we have enumeration underneath,
those are two subtypes.

74
00:04:37,120 --> 00:04:40,350
So we've just moved into
the second half of scanning.

75
00:04:40,350 --> 00:04:45,548
>> That's the stuff that's being exposed
either through normal processes.

76
00:04:45,548 --> 00:04:49,620
We haven't used anything
to break anything or

77
00:04:49,620 --> 00:04:52,350
just to tag, like for
example, we scan open ports.

78
00:04:52,350 --> 00:04:54,940
We find a port that's open, and
it probably should be open for

79
00:04:54,940 --> 00:04:55,780
some reason or other,

80
00:04:55,780 --> 00:04:59,190
it's providing a particular service, and
we're just taking advantage of that.

81
00:04:59,190 --> 00:05:03,410
And we're leveraging that in a way that
maybe they didn't intend us to do.

82
00:05:03,410 --> 00:05:08,211
But we're really not breaking anything yet
or as far as the hacking concept goes.

83
00:05:08,211 --> 00:05:12,030
>> Yeah and
that's an important thing is that we're

84
00:05:12,030 --> 00:05:14,518
really not breaking
anything at this point.

85
00:05:14,518 --> 00:05:18,530
The information that's offered here is
information that's supposed to be offered

86
00:05:18,530 --> 00:05:20,390
for various reasons.

87
00:05:20,390 --> 00:05:25,590
Lists of user names may be offered for
some sort of software functionality.

88
00:05:25,590 --> 00:05:30,459
Lists of shares may be offered because of
something that the network has to have

89
00:05:30,459 --> 00:05:31,137
running.

90
00:05:31,137 --> 00:05:37,775
It may need to enumerate the shares that
are available on a system to attach to it.

91
00:05:37,775 --> 00:05:41,025
It could definitely be
something like that.

92
00:05:41,025 --> 00:05:46,725
Some of this stuff is done,
some of the stuff we already enumerated is

93
00:05:46,725 --> 00:05:52,485
required for that network to function
the way it needs to function.

94
00:05:52,485 --> 00:05:57,750
Some of this stuff also, interestingly
enough, is easy to enumerate because

95
00:05:57,750 --> 00:06:02,830
at one point in the past it was necessary
to have that and no one shut that off.

96
00:06:02,830 --> 00:06:06,211
You know,
NetBIOS I'm looking your direction.

97
00:06:06,211 --> 00:06:06,800
>> [LAUGH] Right.

98
00:06:06,800 --> 00:06:10,470
>> So
that's something that a lot of devices,

99
00:06:10,470 --> 00:06:14,590
in the Microsoft world especially,
they have that enabled, but

100
00:06:14,590 --> 00:06:18,370
there's really not a good reason for
it in a lot of cases to have that enabled.

101
00:06:18,370 --> 00:06:22,070
It's just something that was enabled for
legacy support and

102
00:06:22,070 --> 00:06:23,530
it's up to you to kind of turn it off.

103
00:06:23,530 --> 00:06:28,559
And one of the things we talked about
earlier in this whole course was that

104
00:06:28,559 --> 00:06:33,754
it's, ideally we'd like to have a system
that everything is shut down and

105
00:06:33,754 --> 00:06:36,420
we turn on the things that we need.

106
00:06:36,420 --> 00:06:40,771
That goes towards like least privilege,
that concept as well, and need to know,

107
00:06:40,771 --> 00:06:42,080
stuff like that.

108
00:06:42,080 --> 00:06:43,290
Lock it down.

109
00:06:43,290 --> 00:06:48,098
And then whatever you don't need, or
whatever you do need, turn it on.

110
00:06:48,098 --> 00:06:51,730
But that's not, Microsoft has
kind of learned that lesson, but

111
00:06:51,730 --> 00:06:55,450
it's not 100% across the board and
I'm picking on Microsoft,

112
00:06:55,450 --> 00:06:57,150
they're not the only one that does that.

113
00:06:57,150 --> 00:07:00,220
Every vendor does that
to a certain degree.

114
00:07:00,220 --> 00:07:04,000
I'm just talking NetBIOS in the Microsoft
world and Microsoft turns it on.

115
00:07:04,000 --> 00:07:08,810
The reason why they leave something
like that on is because they figure you

116
00:07:08,810 --> 00:07:10,750
might have older clients and

117
00:07:10,750 --> 00:07:13,530
they wanna leave that on so
you can be compatible with them.

118
00:07:13,530 --> 00:07:15,690
But the reality is most
of us don't need it.

119
00:07:15,690 --> 00:07:16,930
So remember that.

120
00:07:16,930 --> 00:07:20,690
We'll talk more about NetBIOS in a bit,

121
00:07:20,690 --> 00:07:25,610
but do remember that is that some of
this stuff is just legacy stuff that

122
00:07:25,610 --> 00:07:31,220
was left on which may leave the door open
enough for us to get in and check things.

123
00:07:31,220 --> 00:07:31,830
>> Absolutely, yeah.

124
00:07:31,830 --> 00:07:35,376
Microsoft has always been
really good about, I think,

125
00:07:35,376 --> 00:07:39,210
providing that backwards compatibility,
not forcing us to upgrade

126
00:07:39,210 --> 00:07:43,180
everything all at once,
giving us the ability to migrate slowly.

127
00:07:43,180 --> 00:07:46,705
But that does open the door for
vulnerabilities because the newer stuff

128
00:07:46,705 --> 00:07:50,064
is patched up against it, but
the older stuff still relies on that.

129
00:07:50,064 --> 00:07:54,518
Yeah, I think NetBIOS, I've been saying
it's been going away since, I don't know,

130
00:07:54,518 --> 00:07:55,431
2003 maybe.

131
00:07:55,431 --> 00:07:58,777
>> [LAUGH]
>> And Windows XP and here it is 2015, and

132
00:07:58,777 --> 00:08:00,915
it's Still hanging around.

133
00:08:00,915 --> 00:08:04,393
Although, I think it's on it's last leg,
finally with 2012.

134
00:08:04,393 --> 00:08:06,180
But I say that, it'll be in 2014.

135
00:08:06,180 --> 00:08:11,545
>> Yeah, I don't know if I even wanna go
that far and say, it's finally going away.

136
00:08:11,545 --> 00:08:14,120
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's almost like

137
00:08:14,120 --> 00:08:16,410
the super villains in these comic books.

138
00:08:16,410 --> 00:08:20,052
Oh The Green Goblin has been,
Spiderman finally got him and

139
00:08:20,052 --> 00:08:21,800
its like ten issues later he's back.

140
00:08:21,800 --> 00:08:24,180
What?
No one stays dead in comic books,

141
00:08:24,180 --> 00:08:28,920
no one stays dead, nothing really
goes away in the computer world.

142
00:08:28,920 --> 00:08:32,420
So it kinda seems like that sometimes.

143
00:08:32,420 --> 00:08:37,010
You know, we've heard what,
wins has been going away forever?

144
00:08:37,010 --> 00:08:39,390
>> Yeah.
>> And it's still there.

145
00:08:39,390 --> 00:08:42,370
>> It's still a role I
can install in 2012 R2.

146
00:08:42,370 --> 00:08:45,660
>> Yeah, it's absolutely still there,

147
00:08:45,660 --> 00:08:50,730
and how many times have you
taught a class yourself and.

148
00:08:50,730 --> 00:08:52,900
Asked if I do this whenever
whenever WINS comes up.

149
00:08:52,900 --> 00:08:56,080
Ask people do you use
WINS on your network?

150
00:08:56,080 --> 00:08:57,300
Yeah.
We still have it out there.

151
00:08:57,300 --> 00:08:58,244
Do you know why?

152
00:08:58,244 --> 00:08:59,560
>> No I didn't
>> No.

153
00:08:59,560 --> 00:09:01,470
It was just there when they came in and

154
00:09:01,470 --> 00:09:03,580
no one wants to shut it off
cuz they're kind of worried.

155
00:09:03,580 --> 00:09:04,220
They're like, it's there.

156
00:09:04,220 --> 00:09:06,550
There's gotta be a reason that it's there,
right?

157
00:09:06,550 --> 00:09:07,120
>> Right?

158
00:09:07,120 --> 00:09:09,950
>> So
they just leave it hanging out you know?

159
00:09:09,950 --> 00:09:15,040
And that is a pen testers
dream to find that,

160
00:09:15,040 --> 00:09:18,250
because it's leaving a big door open for
you.

161
00:09:18,250 --> 00:09:21,840
It's a hackers dream to find that as well.

162
00:09:21,840 --> 00:09:26,400
So, we kind of wanna ask questions,
in my pen tester experience for example,

163
00:09:27,730 --> 00:09:33,580
if I find winds or I will, you know, ask
questions, why is it there, I don't know.

164
00:09:33,580 --> 00:09:35,030
That's unacceptable to me.

165
00:09:35,030 --> 00:09:38,460
If you say I don't know, find out.

166
00:09:38,460 --> 00:09:41,000
It may be kind of harsh
to say it to a client or

167
00:09:41,000 --> 00:09:43,830
something, why's he ordering me around.

168
00:09:43,830 --> 00:09:45,260
That's what you brought me in for.

169
00:09:45,260 --> 00:09:48,130
Find out, find me a reason So why it is

170
00:09:48,130 --> 00:09:52,091
I'm just gonna do it the easy way unplug
it and wait till someone complains.

171
00:09:52,091 --> 00:09:52,972
>> It's not a bad option right?

172
00:09:52,972 --> 00:09:53,570
>> It works.

173
00:09:53,570 --> 00:09:54,612
it gets the job done.

174
00:09:54,612 --> 00:09:56,470
>> Exactly.
You know and nobody calls and

175
00:09:56,470 --> 00:09:57,970
they never even noticed you turn it off.

176
00:09:57,970 --> 00:09:59,652
There's no problem and
just leave that thing off.

177
00:09:59,652 --> 00:10:02,275
>> I think I found out why I
don't work full time for anybody.

178
00:10:02,275 --> 00:10:04,230
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'd just go and start unplugging stuff.

179
00:10:04,230 --> 00:10:05,950

40
00:02:22,374 --> 00:02:27,540

41
00:02:27,540 --> 00:02:29,145

42
00:02:29,145 --> 00:02:31,870

43
00:02:31,870 --> 00:02:35,260

44
00:02:35,260 --> 00:02:37,560

45
00:02:37,560 --> 00:02:40,850

46
00:02:40,850 --> 00:02:43,410
It's an amalgamation of those two terms.

47
00:02:43,410 --> 00:02:45,110
So what does that really mean?

48
00:02:45,110 --> 00:02:49,584
Well, if I say bad software,
everyone I'm sure is gonna have their

49
00:02:49,584 --> 00:02:54,387
own opinion of what bad software is,
but we're not talking about that.

50
00:02:54,387 --> 00:02:55,456
>> Bing?
>> Yeah.

51
00:02:55,456 --> 00:03:01,220
[LAUGH] Yeah, exactly.

52
00:03:01,220 --> 00:03:06,900
Malware is an umbrella term that
covers things like viruses,

53
00:03:06,900 --> 00:03:10,480
worms, Trojans,
just a whole range of things.

54
00:03:10,480 --> 00:03:14,160
It's software that really
doesn't offer anything, but

55
00:03:14,160 --> 00:03:19,600
at the same time it takes stuff or
does something counter to what you want.

56
00:03:19,600 --> 00:03:21,880
Or works against you, something like that.

57
00:03:21,880 --> 00:03:24,440
That's what we're really talking about.

58
00:03:24,440 --> 00:03:28,950
>> So anything that really does
something that I either didn't want or

59
00:03:28,950 --> 00:03:32,480
didn't need or didn't expect, right?

60
00:03:32,480 --> 00:03:33,740
>> Exactly.
>> Could be malware.

61
00:03:33,740 --> 00:03:34,840
So it could be malicious.

62
00:03:34,840 --> 00:03:35,780
It could be damaging.

63
00:03:35,780 --> 00:03:38,560
But it's definitely
something that I don't want.

64
00:03:38,560 --> 00:03:40,240
>> Yeah, absolutely.

65
00:03:40,240 --> 00:03:42,570
That's the important thing about it.

66
00:03:42,570 --> 00:03:48,200
It's a big term, and as we're saying,
malware is used in a lot of places.

67
00:03:48,200 --> 00:03:52,770
You'll see malware used,

68

72

Malware.

73

74

75

That's really what it is.

76

>> Right, right.

80
00:04:26,800 --> 00:04:27,740
Okay.

81

93

94

96

They also throw adware in there too.

97
00:05:15,980 --> 00:05:17,537
Even though we won't

98
00:05:17,537 --> 00:05:22,537
That's something that's not really
targeted towards what we do or

99
00:05:22,537 --> 00:05:27,550
it's not really in the same ballpark,
so we won't worry about it.

100
00:05:27,550 --> 00:05:29,210
But it is thrown in there.

101
00:05:29,210 --> 00:05:32,230
Then we also have root kits, as well.

102
00:05:32,230 --> 00:05:37,310
Those are all nasty pieces of software,
some nastier than others.

103
00:05:37,310 --> 00:05:40,646
But those are all under that
umbrella of malware, but

104
00:05:40,646 --> 00:05:44,610
each do something specific and
do it a specific way.

105
00:05:44,610 --> 00:05:49,501
And that, just to put it out there right
up front, is that you need to be able to,

106
00:05:49,501 --> 00:05:53,516
when you talk about each one of
these different types of malware,

107
00:05:53,516 --> 00:05:57,750
you need to distinguish why that

108
00:05:57,750 --> 00:06:02,295
Why a virus is a virus and
why a virus is different than a worm.

109
00:06:02,295 --> 00:06:03,838
You need to be able to do
that by the time we're done.

110
00:06:03,838 --> 00:06:08,570
>> Mm-hm, I never had any
luck phishing with viruses.

111
00:06:08,570 --> 00:06:09,878
>> Yeah, yeah exactly.

112
00:06:09,878 --> 00:06:12,961
[LAUGH]
>> All right, so

113
00:06:12,961 --> 00:06:14,976
we've got a bunch of different
categories then, and

114
00:06:14,976 --> 00:06:17,190
we really need to be able to
understand what makes a virus.

115
00:06:17,190 --> 00:06:18,140
What makes a worm?

116
00:06:18,140 --> 00:06:19,230
What makes a Trojan?

117
00:06:19,230 --> 00:06:21,120
And there are some gray areas, right?

118
00:06:21,120 --> 00:06:24,440
I know some of these things might ride
the fence on these different categories.

119
00:06:24,440 --> 00:06:29,390
But in general, we've got some definitions
I guess, I won't say rules, but

120
00:06:29,390 --> 00:06:33,130
some rules to the categories
of what makes a virus,

121
00:06:33,130 --> 00:06:35,740
what makes a worm, and a Trojan,
and a rootkit, things like that.

122
00:06:35,740 --> 00:06:38,660
So that's what we need to know for
this exam.

123
00:06:38,660 --> 00:06:40,700
So let's start with the first one,

124
00:06:40,700 --> 00:06:43,770
the one that everybody's probably at
least familiar with the term of virus.

125
00:06:43,770 --> 00:06:45,810
And it's probably one of
those overused terms.

126
00:06:45,810 --> 00:06:49,583
I think just about, like to my father,
everything is a virus, right?

127
00:06:49,583 --> 00:06:50,320
>> Absolutely.
>> I mean, it doesn't matter.

128
00:06:50,320 --> 00:06:53,730
If he gets a thing in email that
he didn't ask for, that's a virus.

129
00:06:53,730 --> 00:06:56,440
It doesn't really matter what he gets,
it's all a virus.

130
00:06:56,440 --> 00:06:57,660
But that's not true, right?

131
00:06:57,660 --> 00:06:58,880
Not everything is a virus.

132
00:06:58,880 --> 00:07:00,130
>> No, definitely not.

133
00:07:00,130 --> 00:07:04,250
A virus is, and a worm,
just to kind of throw that in there, too.

134
00:07:04,250 --> 00:07:06,570
But we'll stick with viruses first.

135
00:07:06,570 --> 00:07:10,815
That term is very, very overused, and
it's quite frequently used incorrectly.

136
00:07:10,815 --> 00:07:15,510
Anything bad that happens on
a system is automatically a virus,

137
00:07:15,510 --> 00:07:16,820
and that's not true.

138
00:07:16,820 --> 00:07:20,650
Some of it could be user error,
but once we eliminate those,

139
00:07:20,650 --> 00:07:23,860
not every piece of malware that
gets on a system is a virus.

140
00:07:23,860 --> 00:07:28,025
There are things that are malware
that are not viruses,

141
00:07:28,025 --> 00:07:30,220
as we've already kind of discussed.

142
00:07:30,220 --> 00:07:35,920
You know so what we kinda wanna get
into is why a virus is a virus and

143
00:07:35,920 --> 00:07:38,920
why it's not thrown into one
of the other categories.

144
00:07:38,920 --> 00:07:40,980
For something to be
categorized as a virus,

145
00:07:40,980 --> 00:07:45,360
it has to be something that's really,
it has a host.

146
00:07:45,360 --> 00:07:47,460
It invades that host.

147
00:07:47,460 --> 00:07:53,670
And relies on something to happen
to get it to start its infection.

148
00:07:53,670 --> 00:07:54,880
That's really what it is.

149
00:07:54,880 --> 00:07:58,000
And that really distinguishes
it from other things.

150
00:07:58,000 --> 00:08:01,920
Is that if you have something
that's infected by a virus.

151
00:08:01,920 --> 00:08:05,946
You start that application or
start whatever it is and

152
00:08:05,946 --> 00:08:11,680
that triggers the actual infection
to take place at that point.

153
00:08:11,680 --> 00:08:15,830
>> Yeah, and I always think of viruses
as needing our help to reproduce.

154
00:08:16,970 --> 00:08:19,700
They're typically attached to a file or

155
00:08:19,700 --> 00:08:24,830
some type of document, and what happens
is when you click on that file or

156
00:08:24,830 --> 00:08:28,730
that document that's infected,
that virus can then load up into memory.

157
00:08:28,730 --> 00:08:31,140
And can try to attach itself
to other documents or

158
00:08:31,140 --> 00:08:32,660
other things you're working with.

159
00:08:32,660 --> 00:08:35,720
Because all of that resides
in your RAM at that point.

160
00:08:35,720 --> 00:08:40,090
And then when you save something and email
it to somebody else, and you save it, and

161
00:08:40,090 --> 00:08:41,655
now it's got a copy of that Virus with it.

162
00:08:41,655 --> 00:08:44,755
You email it to somebody else,
they open up that file,

163
00:08:44,755 --> 00:08:46,395
it now resides in their memory.

164
00:08:46,395 --> 00:08:48,595
And it starts infecting
everything in their memory.

165
00:08:48,595 --> 00:08:51,375
They start sharing files and
things like that and it starts spreading.

166
00:08:51,375 --> 00:08:54,385
But if you wouldn't have opened
up that file in the first place,

167
00:08:54,385 --> 00:08:56,265
that virus might not have
been able to reproduce.

168
00:08:56,265 --> 00:08:57,135
>> Yeah, absolutely.

169
00:08:57,135 --> 00:08:59,215
And you hit the nail on the head.

170
00:08:59,215 --> 00:09:02,405
I use the more generic term on it.

171
00:09:02,405 --> 00:09:06,410
But yeah, you're absolutely right
to put in crystal terms in there.

172
00:09:06,410 --> 00:09:08,730
Remember, a virus needs a host.

173
00:09:08,730 --> 00:09:09,230
>> Yeah.

174
00:09:09,230 --> 00:09:12,475
>> It needs a host to
start all its nastiness.

175
00:09:12,475 --> 00:09:14,370
>> Mm-hm.
>> You know, now what that host is,

176
00:09:14,370 --> 00:09:18,170
it could be an application file,
which a lot of times it is.

177
00:09:18,170 --> 00:09:20,140
It can be some other stuff too.

178
00:09:20,140 --> 00:09:23,800
But once they're there,
they need something to really

179
00:09:23,800 --> 00:09:26,710
set them off to make them go ahead and
do their nastiness.

180
00:09:26,710 --> 00:09:31,230
And that's why there's so
many different types of viruses out there.

181
00:09:31,230 --> 00:09:32,640
That's the other thing on it as well,

182
00:09:32,640 --> 00:09:37,480
is that there's not just one type of virus
there's a whole family tree of viruses.

183
00:09:37,480 --> 00:09:40,700
Each one having its own
characteristics and

184
00:09:40,700 --> 00:09:42,600
behavior that you really
need to be aware of.

185
00:09:42,600 --> 00:09:49,050
It's actually quite amazing when you start
looking at the whole taxonomy of viruses.

186
00:09:49,050 --> 00:09:50,900
>> It's a good way to put it,
I like that, taxonomy.

187
00:09:52,125 --> 00:09:56,328
They call them viruses,
they use the term taxonomy, and

188
00:09:56,328 --> 00:09:59,756
it is similar to looking
at an evolution tree.

189
00:09:59,756 --> 00:10:02,607
The way these viruses
evolved over time and

190
00:10:02,607 --> 00:10:06,170
have added new functionality and
new capabilities,

191
00:10:06,170 --> 00:10:11,460
and you hate to say it, but some of
them are very elegant and impressive.

192
00:10:11,460 --> 00:10:14,090
I hate to say that I'm impressed
by some of these malware, but

193
00:10:14,090 --> 00:10:17,900
the way it works,
the coders were ingenious.

194
00:10:17,900 --> 00:10:20,525
>> Yes, some of these guys are just
brilliant when you look at them.

195
00:10:20,525 --> 00:10:23,896
They have their own beauty about
them that these people have created.

00:08:28,313 --> 00:08:32,183

00:08:32,183 --> 00:08:34,191

00:08:34,191 --> 00:08:37,887

186
00:08:37,887 --> 00:08:40,239

187
00:08:40,239 --> 00:08:42,319
